awd_titl_txt: RII Track-4:  Applying Transient Reflectance Spectroscopy to Decipher the Impact of Energetics and Electronic Coupling on Interfacial Recombination in Hybrid Halide Perovskites
awd_abstract_narration:
Hybrid organic-inorganic halide perovskites (HPs) are promising materials for use in next-generation solar cells and light-emitting diodes (LEDs).  Further improvements in the performance and stability of these materials and devices will help enable mechanically flexible, lightweight, and inexpensive solar cells and LEDs that may be used in disaster relief areas, in military applications, and broadly deployed to help create a more secure and sustainable energy future. In both solar cells and LEDs, the HP is sandwiched between charge-transporting layers that serve to remove or inject charge carriers (either holes or electrons) into the HP.  Interfaces between the HP and these transporting layers are the dominant areas where harmful non-radiative recombination processes occur, which can lower light generation efficiency and increase heat loss.  Thus, it is essential to better understand these interfaces and identify means to reduce interfacial recombination rates.  This research will directly probe recombination rates at HP interfaces with various transport layers using transient reflectance spectroscopy through a collaboration with Dr. Matthew Beard at the National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL).  The Graham group has worked extensively on understanding and manipulating the surface chemistry of HPs.  Through this grant, the Graham group will be able to directly probe how changes in surface chemistry impact interfacial charge recombination rates.  The findings of this research will help accelerate the development of HPs for solar cells and LEDs, while the collaboration with NREL will help transfer knowledge from the nation's premier renewable energy research facility to researchers in Kentucky.  

Charge-transfer processes at interfaces are one of the most relevant processes determining the performance of electronic and optoelectronic devices, yet these interfacial processes remain much less understood than those occurring within the bulk of the materials.  The goal of this proposed research is to use HPs as a platform to characterize how energetics and electronic coupling influence interfacial recombination processes through the application of transient reflectance spectroscopy. Transient reflectance relies on ultrafast laser pulses to monitor charge carrier recombination dynamics specifically at interfaces, thereby providing a powerful tool to differentiate interfacial recombination from recombination occurring within the bulk of the HP.  Ultimately, the research will test the hypothesis that interfacial recombination rates can be significantly reduced through manipulating the interfacial energy landscape and electronic coupling at interfaces between dissimilar materials using surface modifiers.  Previous research has investigated surface and bulk recombination in pure HPs in both single crystal and polycrystalline film formats, but these investigations have not been extended to include the presence of charge transport layers.  Recombination rates have also been investigated within completed PV devices, but in these complete devices it is not possible to identify where recombination is occurring; thus, targeted approaches to reduce recombination are hindered.  In this proposed research the principal investigator and a graduate student will work with Dr. Beard at NREL on applying transient reflectance spectroscopy to directly probe recombination rates at these important interfaces.  Combining these transient reflectance measurements with ultraviolet and inverse photoelectron spectroscopy will uncover how interfacial energetics and electronic coupling impact interfacial recombination, thereby helping to guide the development of improved solar cells and LEDs based on HPs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

The project was focused on using time-resolved spectroscopies to understand how interfacial chemistry impacts charge-carrier recombination dynamics at interfaces between organic semiconductors and organic metal halide perovskites (HPs). These interfaces play a crucial role in determining the performance of organic metal halide perovskite solar cells (PSCs), and understanding the connections between surface chemistry, interfacial energetics, recombination dynamics, and PSC performance is important for their further development. During the initial phase of the project the researchers worked at the National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) to fabricate and characterize PSCs, with this knowledge being transferred back to the researchers’ laboratory at the University of Kentucky. Through PSC testing and characterization combined with spectroscopic measurements, a family of surface ligands was identified and subjected to further study. These surface ligands were selected for their ability to bind to the HP surface and alter the energy landscape between the HP and the electron transporting fullerene C60 layer. Through applying transient absorbance (TA) and transient reflectance (TR) spectroscopy to the HP/C60 bilayer films, it was determined that all the surface ligands increased the charge carrier lifetime relative to the unmodified control HP/C60 bilayer. This increase in charge carrier lifetime is advantageous for improving PSC performance. Despite the differences in PSC performance between cells modified with different surface ligands, the TA and TR displayed nearly identical recombination dynamics. Transient photovoltage (TPV) and transient photocurrent (TPC) were applied to further probe recombination dynamics in completed PSCs. These measurements showed that the recombination rate is nearly constant for all ligands at a given charge carrier density in the PSC; however, the highest performing surface ligand results in an increased open circuit voltage at a given charge-carrier density relative to the lower performing surface ligands. By applying ultraviolet photoemission spectroscopy, it was determined that the open circuit voltage and PSC performance depend on the interfacial energy gap between the valence band of the HP and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital of C60. These results improve the understanding of how interfacial energetics impact recombination dynamics and solar cell performance.

In addition to the primary work, the researchers developed important collaborations with researchers at NREL. These collaborations led to three additional publications in peer-reviewed scientific journals with NREL researchers. Furthermore, a different graduate student from the Graham laboratory at the University of Kentucky is now working at NREL through a Department of Energy, Office of Science, Graduate Student Research Program award. These collaborations will benefit researchers at NREL and the University of Kentucky, thereby, helping to maximize the complementary strengths of researchers at both institutions.

Broader Impacts

The broader impacts of the award span several different categories. From a technological perspective, the results of the work will help the development of PSCs. These PSCs have the potential to play a major role in promoting energy independence, decreasing greenhouse gas emissions, and enabling the US to increase domestic solar cell manufacturing. Here, the understanding of how surface ligands impact these PSCs may lead to more efficient development of commercial scale PSCs. The project enabled significant transfer of expertise from NREL to the University of Kentucky, thereby, helping to accelerate research progress at the University of Kentucky and strengthen the education of six graduate students, one undergraduate student, and one high school student working in the Graham laboratory. The authors gave several talks on the work, including at scientific conferences and primarily undergraduate serving institutions. One graduate student received significant training under this award and is now a post-doctoral researcher at NREL; however, the knowledge transfer between the PI, graduate student, and NREL researchers has enhanced the education of all students in the Graham laboratory. In general, the collaborations developed between researchers at the University of Kentucky and NREL have the potential to tremendously enhance the training of students and post-docs well beyond the time frame of this award.
